conclusion: To determine the magnitude of the resultant Ampere force on the three resistance wires, analyze the forces acting on each segment of the triangle and sum them up.
The triangle is equilateral, meaning all sides are equal. Denote the length of each side as L. The current flows from point A to point B, then splits into two segments AC and BC.
The current is split equally between AC and BC, so I_AC = I_BC = I/2.
The magnetic force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by F = B I L sin(θ).
For the AB segment: Length L_AB = L, Current I_AB = I, Angle θ_AB = 0°.
The force on AB is F_AB = B I L sin(0°) = 0.
For the AC and BC segments: Length L_AC = L_BC = L, Current I_AC = I_BC = I/2, Angle θ_AC = θ_BC = 60°.
The force on AC and BC are F_AC = F_BC = B (I/2) L (√3/2) = B I L √3/4.
The forces on AC and BC are equal in magnitude but opposite in direction, so their resultant force is zero.
The resultant force on the three segments is F_resultant = F_AB + F_AC + F_BC = 0 + B I L √3/4 + B I L √3/4 = B I L √3/2.
The magnitude of the resultant Ampere force on the three resistance wires is B I L √3/2.
